- Service level, facilities and design meet highest standards- perfect midtown location- one of the few Manhattan hotels with direct view on Central Park- Very nice asiatic interior design in the hall and in the rooms- spacious rooms, very large bathrooms- all possible room amenities, free wifi- excellent room service- attentive front desk service- average swimming pool with nice view on city- Negative: bar and part of the restaurant with clinical ambience, like a train station

Great service, wonderful rooms (you should ask for park view it's very nice). Everything in place, on time. Wide range of felicities (restaurant, spa, fitness etc.). Great location very close to Central Park. I can recommend this hotel to anyone exception hight quality service, although it is expensive.

My family (myself, wife and two children - girls ages 7 & 9) stayed for 4 nights at the Mandarin on Columbus Circle. We stayed in a very spacious suite and paid approximately $1,200/night. I mention the price because I was totally shocked that they would charge me for daily Internet use (I believe it was $19.99/day). So I shell out $1,200 a night for the hotel and then they ask for $19.99? This makes me crazy! What could have been an almost perfect stay at the Mandarin turned into Mandarin management: we live in a new world. The Internet is almost as important as water. To be frank, I would rather be charged for water or electricity use than for the Internet. This may sound exaggerated but it really isn't that far from reality. The Mandarin needs to be ahead of the curve if they want to maintain their pristine reputation. I can understand why many of the marginal hotel chains still charge for the Internet - I still think it is short sighted but it is understandable as they aren't able to charge a high room rate like the Mandarin. Take a look at budget hotels such as Comfort Suites, they are not charging for Internet and in my opinion, it really adds to the experience (wow is Comfort Suites beating the Mandarin in an important customer service area?) Charge me $1,219.99 for your room but don't charge me $1,200 and an Internet fee. Be progressive, stay ahead of the curve. Thanks for listening to my raving.

This is a nice hotel. A very nice hotel. But it is absurdly, nonsensically overpriced. I wasn't paying, and I was booked there by my boss, but I was still offended. What this hotel offers is a view. It's up high and you can see New York from a spectacular vantage point. Everything else - rooms, food, bar, concierge - are really not amazingly better (but certainly more expensive) than countless other New York hotels. If you want a comfortable room, don't worry too much about the view, and don't want to feel like you have been rather fleeced, don't stay here.
Top NY Address. Great Location. Breathtaking views over CP.

I absolutely adore this hotel. Stayed in it just when they opened and now came back with friends. It is still comes out top on service and attentiveness. The spa is to die for and they got an extensive spa menu to choose from. The beds are very cosy and you'll get a great nights sleep. The bathrooms have a great bathtub with views out over NY. Actually, it is hard to find anything to fault this hotel.

3 nights in a Central Park Suite (actually on corner of building, so we had a great cityscape view of Central PArk South and the park). Staff is courteous and correct. Property is immaculate. Suite was spacious. Bathroom A+ with great water pressure, soaking tub, and the best shower I have ever had. Decor is understated and pleasant.There was one clitch with housekeeping, but management promptly and graciously handled it.The bars were a bit uncomfortable and noisy. Okay for a sip and a snack, but not ideal for lounging IMHO. Breakfast in Asiate restaurant was great and reasonably priced.The location is just ideal.The overall ambience is just a little "cool" for my taste compared to the RC and Essex. Others will likely appreciate it, but it seemed lacking in human touch or warmth. But kudos to management for this beautifu and luxurious property.
Wonderful view, great food, location as well. A Real Delight !

Booked a suite for Valentines weekend, in a word... FABULOUS. Our suite had a killer view of the Hudson. What really made our weekend was the attention to detail, nothing was overlooked. We made a reservation for dinner at Asiate and while my S.O. was getting ready, I went down to the bar for a pre-dinner cocktail. The bar was busy but I was quickly taken care of quickly and when a seat opened, my drink was moved and some snacks appeared. That is definately not what I have experienced in other Hotel bars and it really set the tone for a great evening. Next we went to Asiate and they had a Valentines tasting dinner tha was superb. She ordered the champagne pairing and I ordered the wine paring, I usually have difficulty remembering the pairings and don't like the blackberry thing at dinner, I asked for a pen and pad and was surprised that when the waiter brought it, they read my mind and produced the pairings already typed out, now that is service. The food was excellent, the Kobe beef trio is not to be missed and the desert was fabulous as well. I will definately say that the true high point was sleeping in on Valentines morning (the sheets were great) and ordering room service for 11am. It arrived prescisly at 11 and it was presented with great joy by our waiter. There was even a little surprise of a blueberry smoothie...The difference here is the staff, they really make you feel like a VIP.All in all a wonderful weekend and we look forward to next time
there are no words for this Hotel.simply a temple.maybe the staff could be much more nice but....after all....it is a fantastic place.

Up until our stay at the MO in New York, I had placed The Peninsula Chicago at the top of my favorite U.S. hotels list; the MO is now at the top of the list. It's everything an uber-expensive five star city hotel should be. You can't beat the location -- perfectly placed at the southwest corner of Central Park with fabulous views from its Lobby Lounge bar; you're walking distance to all of the top notch shopping and a whole list of sites. The service is impeccable; anything you could want is proactively offered to you --- from the valet to the bellmen, to the concierge to the spa staff to the lobby lounge staff.....they make you feel like royalty.We had room 4724 (a non-suite room), which had a decent view of the Hudson River. The room was fairly small, but they used the space brilliantly. The marble bathroom with two sinks, rain shower head and separate tub was very large (in a good way). The linens were top notch; and the plasma TV offered a live user friendly TV guide. The room also had a spacious walk-in closet.The spa is one of the most expensive around, but the massages are always extremely good. As soon as you have a room reservation, I highly recommend making a reservation for lunch or afternoon/evening cocktails in the Lobby Lounge that overlooks Central Park. Guests get priority over non-guests, but it's always a good idea to have a reservation to ensure the best available table/view.NB: We phoned the hotel directly and simply asked if they were offering any specials not reflected on the website. They ended up offering us free valet parking, free breakfast and a two category room upgrade -- all just for asking the question (the complimentary room service breakfast was amazing; I requested a To-Go cup for my coffee and the lid was a non-spill lid...just one more small detail they didn't overlook).Amazing hotel; extraordinary staff. A very special treat.
user_name:
RLA
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is in an excellent location for shopping, restaurants, central park!We got upgraded to a corner hudson river view room on floor 53, it had windows all around from the floor to the ceiling, breath taking view, amazing comfortable bed, great rainforest shower, seperate toilet, great pool with stunning view all around! Very helpfull staff and concierge. Would for sure go back we had a great stay!!!!

The Mandarin Oriental is just sublime. I've stayed here several times. By far the best rooms are the suites. The suites are just incredible. Providing almost 1,000 sq feet in Manhattan is beyond amazing. The whole suite has dark wood floors with area rugs. You enter in a foyer that leads to a living room in the corner of the building with INCREDIBLE views. The bedroom sits behind the living room and offers really good views as well. The suite also provides one and a half bathrooms - a nice touch. When the staff member brought us up, after showing us around, he asked if we would like some complimentary coffee, tea, etc. We decided it would be nice for some coffee, and within ten minutes coffee was in our room. Throughout our stay, the Mandarin staff did anything we asked them - dinner reservations in an hour? Sure! Broadway tickets for tonight? Absolutely! You need a new computer chord? Let us run over to the Apple store and get one for you! In all ways this hotel is amazing.

I've stayed in this hotel many times over the years. I like the chain in general and have stayed at their hotels in Miami and Washington DC, but this one is my favorite. It is consistently wonderful and to me epitomizes New York chic (in an Asian kinda way). The design is impeccable. I've stayed in both single rooms and suites. Both are terrific--the suites being particularly terrific, of course. And I like how the rooms are high up (the hotel begins on the 39 floor of one of the towers in the Time Warner Center), thus blocking out all the noise and craziness of The City.The room service menu is excellent. I have also eaten at their restaurant Asiate which is very nice. I like the Lobby Lounge less well, as it tends to be a bit of a scene. But the food is very good and the city views are spectacular. Usually when we stay here, we are with our three young children, so the giant Whole Foods food court in the basement of the building is a real plus. So convenient.The service at this hotel is phenomenal. They really go the extra mile. And the concierge desk sets the gold standard. Those folks really know New York and understand their clientele. I have always found their advice and recommendations to be spot on. Last of all, I will say that you really get to know a hotel when something goes wrong. One time when I was staying here, I left my purse on the floor of a taxi cab. We were leaving the next day and I was justifiably in a panic. I rushed down to the concierge desk at 11:30p and told them what happened. They totally took care of me. The security guy on duty was actually an off-duty cop. He gave me phenomenal advice on stopping my credit cards, etc. Then they drove me down to the police precinct so I could fill out the stolen goods forms. (At the time, I did not know whether the purse was missing or stolen.) As it turned out, a kind gentleman found my purse, tracked me down and returned it before I left town. But I ever so impressed by the hotel's response. In fact, their head of security phoned me at home a few days later to follow up and make sure everything was okay.

Three nights here were enough to convince us this is a good hotel but not a great one. Like most NYC 5-star establishments it’s incredibly expensive and not great value for money. On the plus side, staff here is right on top of the game and could not be faulted on service delivery. Our room on the 54th (top) floor had spectacular views of the Hudson, was comfortable and of a good size but not without its flaws. The worst of these was lighting at night – with all the lights on it was still too dark to read anywhere except in bed or at the desk (not helped by one of the over-bed down-lights being blown and the “night light” not functioning). A cosy chaise lounge by the window was the perfect place for reading but a black hole without a lamp. The single vanity in an otherwise good bathroom was also a disappointment, lacking space to spread a couple’s toiletries around. Nothing to complain about in a lesser hotel, but when you’re paying this much money? On our visit, the hotel’s Asiate restaurant was closed for renovation so breakfast was served in the Lobby Lounge. Great views over Central Park West to the Upper East Side did not compensate for a completely drab and uninspiring à la carte menu – oatmeal that could have been pre-made and pastries served stone cold and so floury they made you gag. (Check out the Greenwich Hotel for how breakfast should be done). Such a pity the warm and engaging service was let down by the kitchen. While the front desk and concierge could not have been more helpful in their duties, the Spa remained unexplored due to extortionate charges. $305 for a 1hour 50 minute massage? Give us a break! Nice pool though. This well-located hotel works fine for an uptown stay but we’d be inclined to try the newly renovated Pierre or Mark hotels next time. Unlike its sister hotels in other locations, the MO NYC doesn’t quite give you what you pay for.

Hi, My wife and I stayed in the Madarin New York for three days prior to a Caribbean Cruise. The hotel has some good features but lacked the atmospher of other NY hotels around Christmas, like the waldorfe. The lobby bar has some good views and the restaurant was good. Also a nice room but let down badly by its lack of soundproofing. We were distubed early every morning either by some inconsiderate neighbours or hotel staff but the noise of anyone talking in ajacent rooms or the corridor carried straight into our room. It really was as though there were people in the room wioth us. At 5.20 am you can really do without this.James. Yorkshire, England

When you ask our kids what did they like most in New York, they will say "our hotel" as their favorite memory. It was outstanding. The rooms are beautiful, the view (central park) extraordinary, the pool a great experience, the service perfect... we were absolutely delighted with our stay. If you can afford it, it is worth the money.We didn't use room service but found anything we needed in the stores at the foot of the hotel building.The restaurant Asiate was a wonderful experience too. We left the kids in the room with DVDs and a pizza while we splurged on the 35th floor. Great.

We had a great room overlooking Central Park. The staff were very good especially the doormen who were good humoured and very helpful.However we had to have maintenance 4 times to our room with niggling problems and technical assistance twice.In addition they charge for Internet use when you already paying a $1000 per night for the room!

I stayed at The Mandarin Oriental NY on Christmas day 2009. I have nothing but good things to say about the hotel. I had requested to check in at 1:00PM and I was able to do so. Upon check in they asked if I would like any tea sent to my room. I asked for white-hot chocolate and it was promptly delivered--with a smile.I had dinner in the Lobby Lounge and it was quite good. Service was excellent. I live in NYC and frequently go there for lunch. I get treated like royalty and the service is always top notch.On a previous visit I was able to book the VIP suite. What an experience that was. It was a little pricey, but it was a nice treat.I highly recommend this hotel. It is a bit pricey but it is SOOOOO worth it

My now fiancee and I stayed here for a weekend (12/18-12/20) and it was amazing. The highlights:+ Big bed+ Great bathroom. Had a bath and separate shower. The shower had one of those rainforest nozzles in addition to a normal nozzle. Everything in the bathroom was marble. They also had the toilet in a separate room, which was nice. Very spacious.+ The room was very large. It was the size of a small apartment.+ We stayed on the 51st floor and had an amazing view of Central Park. The floor to ceiling windows were spectacular.+ The bed had nice linens and was very large.+ They had a sitting couch right next to the window so you could just lounge around and look outwards.+ They upgraded us from a Hudson River room to a Central Park room.+ The reception and concierge staff were all exceedingly friendly.+ Nice LCD TV in the room.+ We went to Asiate (the restaurant in the hotel) and it was definitely top notch. The restaurant has amazing views (which we couldn't see much of due to a blizzard) and the food is outstanding. I even ate Tuna which I normally hate.+ You're only like a ten minute walk from all sorts of shopping (5th Ave, etc...). You can pretty much walk anywhere from here. If you don't feel like walking, there is a subway station right outside too.The only negative I can really think of is that it is extremely expensive to stay here. I stayed here because it was a special weekend, however I normally wouldn't be able to afford to stay here.Overall, if you have the money, I would definitely recommend staying here.

The NYC MO is my favorite of the top-notch hotels in NY. The rooms begin on 39 so the views of Central Park or the Hudson River are very nice. No other top NY hotel offers views to match. Also, the height makes the rooms very quiet for NYC. Asiate restaurant is quite good--modelled after Tetsuya in Sydney. The rooms are large and comfortable. Nearby restaurants are among the best in NY--Jean Georges and so on. Also, the next morning after a great dinner Central Park is next door to jog off the previous eveneing's overindulgence. I have stayed here many times and I have always found it to be excellent.

There are two key points for me about this hotel: 1. It is quite expensive and 2. Everything, for us, in the hotel was pretty much perfect. It has the most fantastic location - just beside Central Park. If you like running (or just walking), you'll love it here! We ran every day before breakfast. When you come back in to the hotel after your run they have water and bananas out for the runners (depending on what time you get back of course - we missed it one day) and we thought that was a great idea. Although you would argue that when you are paying over $1000 per night for the room the least they can do is give you a banana and a bottle of water when you get back in from your run! The hotel also has a lovely swimming pool - it's about 25m - and a gym. Across the road is a 24 hour Starbucks (we're from London where you don't get that so much! So when you wake up at 5am you can get your coffee which is great. I have no doubt that you can order coffee through room service at any time but I didn’t find their coffee quite strong enough in the morning hence my Starbucks visit instead).Breakfast in the hotel is expensive but good. We had an $80 credit every day for breakfast and we used that easily at breakfast and we weren’t trying the whole menu! Our bedroom was wonderful – we had a Central Park room – it had a massive bed and lovely bathroom. I have no idea what the other rooms are like so I can only recommend this one – the views are incredible.We used the spa too – again it’s expensive but good. Although I am a bit of a spa ‘go-er’ and I have been to better in London for half the price. The concierge is also very good and gave us some good restaurant recommendations and the service throughout the hotel was impeccable.
The location is fantastic. The views are mindblowing. The staff are arrogant and snooty and the breakfast was some croissant with condiments.Stay here for the location, but for nothing else.

For those who like staying in midtown and close to the park, location can´t be beat. Service is exquisite, their restaurant is incredible, the central park room views are to die for, but not for US$1200 a night. Of course the room is very beautiful, comfortable, with a huge bed and free amenities, marble bathroom and super shower, but for that price I was expecting a mansion... I can´t actually complain about anything, but I believe that you can find much better value in NY.
Right on Central Park - beautiful view of park. Service is spectacular. They didn't have the type of bagel I wanted for breakfast, so they went over to Whole Foods and bought it for me.

Excellent in all respects with the exception of the extra charge for the internet and the exorbitant charge of $16 for a bowel of cornflakes at breakfast though this did include the milk and a fruit garnish. In spite of my grumpy old man gripes the staff were great, the room comfortable and well appointed, and the breakfast great (a civilised full service meal rather than the usual buffet). The pool and gym are excellent. I am looking forward to my next stay.
the lobby and the room was spectacular....with exceptional service from the multi lingual staff.

Elegant and plush hotel. Tall building and I believe the lounge is on the 35th floor. Sterile entry and security approaches immediately. You can't get to the elevator unless you have a key. Nice restaurant..very unaffordable. In other words, nice but overpriced. Great views.Room was clean, decent size, floor to ceiling windows, comfortable bed and clean shower. Flat screen TV - had WebTV which I used for the first time. Helpful staff. Hotel is near Columbus Circle and attached to Time Warner Building. Many nice restaurants in the area and 24 hour Starbucks directly across the street. Hotel is a very short distance from Central Park which is great for joggers. Shopping mall is located inside Time Warner Building. Hotel is modern, plush with great views and great dining options. Staff will bend over backward to get whatever you need. Great location too & very near subway station.

We stayed at the mandarin oriental in New York for 3 nights in October of 2009. It was for both business and pleasure as I had a meeting but my partner just enjoyed the city. The hotel is beautiful with spectacular views. Rooms were spacious for New York and service was good but not overly intrusive. The lobby bar always had a mix of beautiful and/or rich clientele. The location was good for business and convenient for the park and midtown. It is not as convenient if you tend to like SoHo/Village attractions but still very accessible via subway. My lack of 5 stars is based on cost and value. It is a great hotel but you pay for it. If money is not tight, then it is a wonderful choice.

This was our first time in NYC and we wanted a great hotel. I think we got it. I wasn't 100% happy because I've stayed at a Mandarin Oriental before (in Hong Kong), and the service and quality of room just weren't as great as the HK experience. Whilst I can accept that the different locations can explain the different amenities, an international brand like the Mandarin Oriental should really have the same level of excellent service globally.Gripe out of the way, the experience was amazing. I don't think you could ask for a better view of New York City than from the Mandarin Oriental - it was just like in the magazines and in the movies. We were on the 49th floor and had a great view of Central Park and the skyscrapers in the south easterly direction. The room was very comfortable (if a bit small, but I hear that's the norm). The bathroom felt like it could have been spruced up a bit. The concierge service was a bit hit and miss. But they tried very hard and were genuinely friendly people. Reception/front desk, however, were not very friendly and pretty snooty.The location was also great for everything - shopping (Niketown, Bloomingdales, etc. all a short walk away), theatres (about 15 minutes in a taxi) and most of all restaurants. Jean Georges is just across the road in the Trump Tower and Per Se is in the same building. The hotel is located above a shopping mall, which had some places that I was looking for (e.g., J Crew).Breakfast in the restaurant was pretty excellent, with amazing views, of course. Some city types seem to have breakfast meetings there, which adds to the atmosphere.All in all, a good place to have stayed. Yes, it was expensive, but I don't think there's any other way in NYC.

I love MO NYC. I like the location. I lile the look. I like the feel. I love the spa. The Gentlemen's wet rooms are very seductive. Asiate's views and cuisine provide the best lunch spot in NYC. The service in all areas of the hotel is the best in US. Many of the staff are alum of my previous favorite, Four Seasons. The concierge desk works miracles. They've secured last minute tables at Per Se and Masa for us. If we want to take our nieces downtown they the latest hot spots for the fabulous people. They have even helped us get on a coveted "list" or two. The front desk apprears to always remeber us. We use the Centurion card and always get an upgrade, often a double upgrade. Suites 5100 and 5300 are the best unless you're in the Presidential.

This is probably the freshest/ cleanest feeling luxury hotel in Manhattan. Since NYC can be so gritty we really appreciate that about the Mandarin. The service is definitely not as warm as others we have stayed at but certainly efficient. We did have a problem every day reaching the concierge from the outside, though. The rooms are very nicely appointed with some great park views for a price. We paid with Amex Plat and the hotel was not full but we were not offered an upgrade. The rooms are not huge as you are in NYC. We loved having the access to the basics of the Time Warner Center - reasonable food, bank, etc. The location is not NYC's poshest (Columbus Circle/ Lincoln Center can feel very commercial), but gives you access in all directions.

Was in NYC for 1/2 marathon and stayed at Mandarin Oriental. I was definitely impressed. Booked using a Platinum AMEX which entitles you to a late check-out and room upgrade when available. Had a park view room, although the Trump building blocks some of the view it was still great.ROOMSuper comfortable bed, what it should be for 600 USD night room. Bath tub with great amenities. Nice rain shower head. Delivered complimentary ice tea to room upon check-in. Didn't use internet, but available for like 15 USD a night. Small pet peeve is these high end hotels nickle and diming on internet access.Flat screen TV with HD feed. Great audio system.Room service for breakfast delivered exactly on time as ordered!Nice desk with ample outlets for computer, phone, etc..Two bottles of Fiji Water put in room in the evening when they turn down the beds.LOCATIONAt Columbus Circle in Time Warner building. Had breakfast one morning at Bouchon Bakery on 3rd Floor. Just great! There is also a Whole Foods on ground floor with a lot of healthy options.If $$$ is not a concern go, otherwise consider it a splurge for a special occasion.

I cannot say enough about the Mandarin. The rooms were very spacious with high ceilings, a huge bathroom, floor to ceiling windows and amazing views. The king bed was massive and like sleeping on a cloud. I couldn't find fault with a single thing in the room. If I were being REALLY picky I would say that the only thing I didn't like was that you couldn't get the same channels on the television in the bathroom that you could on the TV in the bedroom. That's it. Really.After a mad day of meetings and running around New York in heels and humidity, I was so ready to shower and relax. The bathroom did not disappoint. Great bath amenities, huge rain shower head, big soft towels and a luxurious robe. Most welcome to my tired feet were the soft slippers. Ahhh. Just as I was debating whether to spoil my upcoming dinner at Asiate by eating something out of the mini-bar (I was ravenous) I hear my door bell ring and someone say "In room dining, good afternoon?" I don't know how, but they read my mind. The Mandarin had sent up a complimentary bento box with truffles, biscotti, mini-cookies and various other treats-- just enough to tide me over until dinner. Dinner at Asiate was out of this world. I told the waiter that I was vegetarian, and they were incredibly accommodating. They made sure to ask if I ate fish, poultry, dairy, eggs-- they made it a perfect dining experience. The food was out of this world. The risotto was spectacular, the drinks were delightfully strong and the desserts were nothing short of sinful. Couple that with spectacular views of Central Park (and the city lights, when it got dark) and you have a dinner that I won't soon forget.One of the things at the Mandarin that really impressed me was the service. Being a five star hotel, of course I expected a certain level of service. However, what impressed me was not the level of service, but the warmth of it. The gentleman who checked us in (Thomas? the name escapes me) was so very personable and warm. You really got the feeling that he enjoyed his job and was truly pleased to be welcoming you to his hotel. Any employee I came across had a genuine smile for me and a greeting. I stayed at a number of different hotels during my week in New York, and the service at the Mandarin was hands-down the most personable, which surprised me.

I have stayed a number of times at the Mandarin in New York for business (last visit Nov 2008).Located in the 35th floor and up of a tower in Columbus Circle, the hotel is right by Central Park and offers amazing views on the park and the Hudson river, as well as the city (even the lowest rooms start on the 37th floor).Rooms are spacious and well designed, with an Asian touch. Some are a little dated, but very well maintained.The hotel has all amenities of a truly 5 star hotel with the service that goes with it. Both restaurants are very good, you can have a light bite at the bar area or a proper dining experience at their michelin star restaurant, both displaying incredible views over the city.The spa is great, large choice of treatments, and has a jaccuzzi/sauna/steam room. The pool is a good 20m long if not more and the gym is excellent filled with modern equipment.Finally, the business center is open all night and has everything you need which is helpful and saved me a few times.This is one of the best hotels I've stayed in. Price is aligned with the hotel category, but definitely not a rip-off, they earn every cent they charge you for.The only negative is the area if you're coming on a leisure trip. I've also stayed downtown which is a more pleasant neighbourhood. It's not bad per se (you have the park, museums, shopping etc) but most people around the hotel are there to work, and I felt that the scene doesn't give you the feeling of what living in New York is like. I'm posting a review on the Soho Grand Hotel soon, which is a good place if you're looking for a holiday.Otherwise for business, I wouldn't go anywhere else.

Just couldn't bring myself to give this hotel a 5 star rating. We never got 2 robes in our suite, regardless of the request. On 2 mornings, the steak and eggs resulted in the meat being well beyond the ordered temperature. The contemporary decor suite with floor to ceiling windows meant the suite had stunning views, but it was only moderate in size. The extra half bath, although poorly lit, is always a welcome amenity. Loved the 'Fresh' bath products and the rain shower.A great urban spa. The men's facilities were first rate.The decor is a bit cold, but that's what you get with this sophisticated minimalist approach. I'm not a fan of Dale Chihuly glass sculpture, so those touches in the public spaces detract from the 'look' in my book.I would stay again.

Great hotels in NY are not cheap. The Mandarin is a great location... On Central Park, Near Midtown, but not as crazy as Times Square. I did a mixed business and leisure trip here for 3 days. Hotel service was superb. Asiate restaurant is tops in the entire City according to Zagat for best views and decor... and it is. Here are some more highlights:* Rooms: Grade: A... Nice, newer, great bathrooms. Had a Hudson River view, Central Park is nicer, but Hudson View from corner rooms was great for us. Surprisingly, our upgraded corner room did not have two sinks in bathroom. If important to you, be sure to ask. Shower was great. I've had NYC rooms that were the size of a coat closet, the king room here was very comfortable. * Mini-Bar: A. In NY, if you want a Diet Coke or a quick snack, I do not know how people survive without a nice mini-bar. They had a great mini-bar with water and drinks. Expensive, yes, BUT THIS IS NY! Many hotels are removing mini-bars, but they are a salvation if you want a Diet Coke or Snack at an odd time.* Spa: A++... Definitely one of the best urban spas anywhere. Great hot tub/pool, steam room, etc. Not cheap, but worth every penny for a massage or other service.* Lobby: A... On the 35th floor, nice lounge area, clean and open space. Good lobby bar with great views. * Concierge: A... arranged all kinds of stuff for us. Friendly and efficient.* Room Service: A-... Generally great. Food and service were excellent. * Asiate: A... Great food, the best view around. Brunch was VERY reasonable. Good wines too. * Lobby Bar food: B+... A friend of mine ate lunch at the lobby bar. He said most of it was good, but some items got cold. Lobby bar is next to Asiate, but they probably do not share a kitchen. His sense was this food came from a kitchen much further and not Asiate. His review of the lukewarm food was the only real criticism we could find at this hotel. * Location: A+... one of the best. * Service: A... great overall. Not over the top, there when you need them. Front desk was busy sometimes, but overall they seem to have a good full staff everywhere. Doorman and concierge helped solve lots of issues. * Other: A+... Hotels are expensive. If you are busy, you need lots of little things taken car of... they had a hotel shuttle take us to a play when we were rushed and booked a great ride to the airport in an Audi A8. Can't say enough about the small stuff. This hotel had a LOT of international guests from Europe and Asia. There were a few groups of loud young twentysomethings on some sort of group party who made a bit of noise, but otherwise this is a great, quiet, professional-focused hotel. Great business hotel and a great leisure hotel if you want to be near Central Park and/or have a great spa. We will return to this hotel again soon. The Mandarin can go head-to-head with the Ritz or Four Seasons and it a bit more modern than the Ritz.

My spouse and I have always afforded at least 1, truly, luxury vacation per year (Maui, HI; Singapore, Jamaica, Mexico, Bahamas, Florida, Vegas, Tahoe. The experience offered by the Mandarin Oriental has topped all the vacations that we have ever taken. The staff was genuinely friendly and exceptional to service. The views from our room and lobby of the Hudson River and Central Park were spectacular. The hotel is located within an easy and entertaining walking distance to everything Manhattan. The subway entrance is just off the corner in Columbus Circle. The entry to the hotel was also very pleasing as it away from the hustle and bustle of Columbus Circle and the many hotels on Broadway, Park and 5th Avenue venues. From the door-staff to direct you to the elevators for the 35th floor lobby, to the reception/check-in, room service, privacy service; everything about this hotel was geared to great and sincere personal service. Prior to booking, I read a few reviews complaining of the noisy Hudson River side of the hotel. We requested the Hudson River side for the views and found no disturbing noise whatsoever, and our room was directly across from the ice-machine and service elevator room. We were on the 51st floor and could hear a faint siren squawk every now and then, but then we were in the largest city in the U.S; I hear more sirens living in Dallas, TX. And, let me mention that we slept like babies; the bed and linens are luxurious, the hairdryer was a real one and not attached to the wall, the spa soaps and lotions divine - I'm very picky/sensitive skin and usually don't bother with these complimentary items, but put some on my tired feet and immediately notice the high quality of the products. Also, superior compliments to room service; we found ourselves in our room each late afternoon to rest and rejuvenate before going back out again in the evening; every afternoon a plate or basket of delicious snacks were waiting our arrival (nuts, garnished popcorn, candied fruits, fresh fruits, chocolates, etc.) - a nice touch to go with our cocktail, which I ordered through room service every late afternoon and here is the point - it arrived quickly, not 30 minutes after ordering, but within minutes. Same with our breakfast room service that we did not pre-order the night before. Room Service within minutes with fine linens, cutlery and china. The coffee, Illy, is one of my favorites. The room-service phone staff was courteous and could actually talk and listen; never seeming impatient or hurried. Exceptional Hotel and one worth spending the money on.
Had a spa day at and it was incredible!! The service, the treatment, the spa facilities....could imagine a better way to spend Sunday!!!!

It is all very well to put lotus flowers on your plates but if the room (overpriced!) is not functional, I'd rather not have them. There is not nearly enough cupboard and drawer space, the sofa has no backrest so you cannot sit on it and read and there is only one chair. Most disappointing though is the lobby - nowhere to sit and rest except if you are prepared to have a snack or drink. Impossible to pour the tea without spilling some of it. On the positive side, we found the staff very friendly and helpful (especially the concierge) and the room on the Central Park side was very quiet. A good mark also for the bathroom with its enclosed shower. Contrary to other Mandarin Oriental Hotels (e.g. Geneva) I would not give this one a top rating and would rather go to a more functional yet cozy place.

The Mandarin NYC is in the midst of it all in midtown Manhattan. It's also "in the mist." Let me explain: while on business in NY, I spent several days at the Mandarin--including Saturday and Sunday rehearsals for an early Monday morning pitch. With some downtime, I was able to explore all the great restaurants in the Time Warner Center (Thomas Keller's place) and nearby restaurants (Jean George). But what was really a treat about the Mandarin--here comes the "mist" part--is the spa. I was able to spend 80 luxurious minutes in the MO spa--including some quality time in the mist in the amethyst steam room. I was then massaged until completely relaxed and ready for the pitch on Monday. So, at the Mandarin, you can be both in the midst and in the mist...doesn't get any better than that.

We stayed at the Mandarin Oriental for 2 nights from May 8th 09, this is simply the best hotel experience you can imagine, words alone cannot explain our sheet delight with the standards of this hotel, the attentive and superbly professional staff and the amazing location just across from Central Park on the Columbus Circle. Book this hotel and you will not be disappointed, we will be back before long!
This was my third trip back to the Mandarin Oriental New York. Stunning views of Central Park , great location and an excellent staff will keep me coming back!

We stayed here to celebrate our wedding anniversary, leaving the children at home. The hotel put us on the top floor in a premium park view suite, at a very reasonable rate. The day we arrived they gave us complimentary champagne and chocolate-dipped strawberries (a personal favourite) which was a lovely touch. The suite was lovely with a far better than average bathroom for a NY hotel (where baths are usually like large sinks)The hotel staff were of the highest quality in every department, with service levels I haven't experienced in any other NY hotel. The spa was great, though expensive. The location on Columbus Circle cannot be bettered in my opinion.The food was disappointing in comparison to other Mandarin Oriental hotels. Room service was OK but not great. The lobby lounge was again OK, not great. Choice of lunch and dinner dishes in both were limited (though breakfast was excellent as always in NY)I didnt find Asiate innovative, or inspiring, but really rather boring (we had the tasting menu). If you've been to the Fat Duck or similar in Europe this restaurant will be a disappointment. It has the NY tendency (just like its neighbour Per Se) to be over elaborate in the preparation of food without really achieving anything remarkable. And at present they are all obsessed with the provenance of the ingredients - I don't really care where the mushroom comes from or how it is grown if it tastes bland....The next day I couldnt remember what I'd eaten at all. On the bright side, the room was spectacular (the "wall of wine" is particularly impressive).I will stay here again - for the rooms, service and location. But will probably eat outside the hotel.

Visited the MO bar for a quiet drink and dinner. Fernando was our waiter and performed exceptional customer service. My colleague requested an item that was not on the menu and Fernando immediately offered to check with the Chef and indicated it would not be a problem. The timing, quality and professionalism of the staff in the bar were memorable. I am also in the Hospitality Industry and like to acknowledge great service.Thank you Fernando.

I love the Mandarin NYC. If I could afford to live here, I would. The service, the rooms, the spa, the workout facilities: the whole place is phenomenal. My room service meal was one of the better meals I have had in my life. The staff is amazing, kind, and helpful. The only downside is the price, but you get what you pay for.

Great hotel - very expensive - is it worth it in these times!? Paid almost $3,000 per night for 1 suite & 1 connected room - great accomodations. Everything about the hotel is great - wonderful view (GWB from 1 room, Central Park sideways from another), everything was perfect. All employees are extremely accomodating, couldn'nt ask for more. Also great location - Columbus Circle at the lower west end of Central Park - can't beat that! Went there for my stepdaughters birthday - she loved the pool (didn't like the fact that spas/whilpools are unisex!),had a birthday cake there when we checked in. All in all a great time, but ?$$$ (but we are in NYC) . If you really want to celebrate, why not!? Do it!!!!

We stayed at the Mandarin Oriental for my birthday weekend at the end of January and it was beyond perfect, it was magical! Luxury hotels tend to feel stuffy and old, whereas the Mandarin Oriental was modern, and warm. The Asian influence is everywhere, but always tasteful and never overdone. What I liked most about the hotel and the suite was how comfortable I felt everywhere. From check-in to check-out, I was always made to feel like a king.The 35th Floor Lobby is exquisite. The Front Desk staff was friendly, accommodating, and genuine. There was nothing scripted or fake about anyone I came in contact with (something I find to be obnoxious at other hotels). The one bedroom, one and half bathroom suite was stunning. The bedroom was exceptionally large and the 2 closets were impressively spacious. Next to the large picture window was a beautiful chaise. The bed was very comfortable and when we asked for non-down bedding, it was brought in an instant. The main bathroom was humongous! It was as long as the room. I loved how it flanked the bed (there was a door on each side of the bed). The rain showerhead and “Fresh” products were lovely as was the soaking tub, his and her sinks, and swiveling TV.I’ve lived in New York City all my life, but standing at the floor-to-ceiling windows, on the 53rd floor, with unbelievable views of the Hudson River, Central Park, and Columbus Circle renewed my love for this city – I could only imagine how awed out-of-towners must be.Dinner at Asiate was an event. We sat at one of the window seats overlooking the park and had a beautiful view as we ate our impressive dinner. This restaurant deserves much more attention than it receives. The service was impeccable and the food was out of this world (I’m still dreaming about the lobster and risotto dishes). The Lobby Lounge was equally as impressive, but obviously with a more casual feel. I’ll always be apprehensive about paying more than $15 for a cocktail, but that apprehension disappeared after the first sip of my beautifully crafted “Baby Buddha”.Overall, I think Mandarin Oriental is the best hotel in New York. It’s different. In a very, very good way.

Don't usually stay in hotels like this, but so glad I did this time! Fab central location, great views, everything in our room was top quality and nothing was too much trouble for any of the charming staff. Spa facilities top notch, although treatments are a bit pricey. Swimming pool and sauna great and lovely products for use in changing rooms.Looking forward to my next visit already!

We stayed at the Mandarin from 15 – 20 September for our honeymoon and it was absolutely amazing. We booked on the Internet Rate and paid $815 dollars/night plus taxes. On arrival the receptionist upgraded us from a Grand Deluxe Double room on the 40th floor (their website says these rooms are on floors 43-54 so not sure if she was downgrading us!) to a Premier Hudson River View room on the 53rd floor. Our room was amazing, exactly as the pictures depict on their website, spotlessly clean, well appointed and with fantastic views of the city and the River Hudson. The bed was super comfy. Excellent sound system, didn’t really use the TV so can’t comment on choice of channels. We’d only been in our room 30 minutes when complimentary champagne and chocolate cake arrived, both were delicious. Housekeeping and turndown service was excellent. We ordered room service a couple of times and it was exceptional. Breakfast in our room was more than adequate but didn’t think it was up to the usual Mandarin standard. We didn’t have much need to use the concierge but when we did they were very helpful and efficient. The bellmen/doormen were all very friendly. We didn’t have time to eat in Asiate but wish we had. We had cocktails and mini burgers (not together!) in the Lobby Lounge, the burgers were great. Hotel location was excellent for us, in a quietish area on the edge of central park but only about a 10 minute walk to Times Square. It’s very much a business hotel so some people may feel it’s a bit ‘clinical’, but all the staff were great and we loved it.

On previous trips while staying at another 5 star property in town, I kept finding myself at The Time Warner center for dinner, drinks, walks in the park etc. Therefore , I thought, why not try it out?While there were no disasters, and nothing particularly bad about the hotel, it came across as dissapointigly average. The park views were terrific. The service was friendly. But the overall experience feels more like a convention Hyatt. There's nothing wrong with that, but its very dissapointing if you are expecting a five star experience. That fifth star is all in the details, and thats what the hotel lacks. From the service, to the finishes in the rooms. Most of the problems come from the building itself. Even though the hotel is only a couple hundred rooms, you definitely feel like you're in a massive structure. And everything, from the spa to the business center feels like its miles away, down random corridors. For example, the entrance to the gym is located just outside a ballroom area: so at best, you have to walk through a dark empty banquet area with a piano covered in the corner, but I couldn't help thinking of the alternative if the room were in use, which would be making your way through a black tie affair in your sweaty workout clothes. One afternoon I returned to my room to find the maid cleaning the room, but noticed she had the TV turned on and was watching a soap opera. Little things like this give the impression there is very little oversight of the smaller details by management. The area rug in the lobby has an ugly rubber band around it like an airport would have, and the tile and fixtures in the bathrooms, while attractive, look cheap and institutional. The rooms have an office-chic feel to them, like a first class airport lounge. Nothing wrong with that, but certainly not the height of luxury one might expect.

Second stay at the Mandarin Oriental. First stay was in a Central Park view suite. This time in a Central Park deluxe room. everything remains excellent with excellent amenities.Actually, this is certainly the best hotel in New York from the bellmen staff to the spa, the restaurants, the concierge and even the whole security. Yes, it has a cost and location is not the best, but it worth the value.

Date: November 14, 2008I have stayed at the Mandarin Oriental in New York previously and had a pleasant stay. This time, however, is typified by the attitude of the Maitre D at the cocktail lounge. We asked for seats and were told, with an arrogant and superior demeanor, that it would be a twenty to twenty-five minute wait. This despite many tables being obviously vacant. We were told we could wait at the bar, which we did. Thirty minutes later the Maitre D having never come for us, I approached him again and was told I would still have to wait. Again, many tables were open. Finally an hour later, after never having heard from the Maitre D, we left. We noted again that most of the tables in the lounge were still vacant. The attitude of the staff was that we were lucky to be there. With these prices and the economy what it is, if they continue with this attitude it is they who will be lucky to be there.

The hotel offers the usual Mandarin Oriental high standards found throughout this chain but in addition it offers wonderful views across Central Park (albeit they are not uninterupted!). Didnt manage to make breakfast. Rooms service was good although clearing trays from the room took hours. What was uncomfortable about the hotel is the distance from 5th Avenue. Yes you are closer to the theatres and you have shopping & dining options downstairs (the hotel is on the higher levels of a Columbus Circle building) but its a stroll to 5th & a stroll back with shopping bags. The Ritz and Plaza beat it for location though. The bar is though a great place to meet & enjoy the views. What is also unusual is that the hotel 'starts' with its lobby on the 35th floor.

This is first review that I have written for any of the hotels in the city. As I wonder why I haven't, the only answer I can come up with is that none of the other "houses" excited me enough to spend the time writing about it. These include the Marquis, Waldorf, Michelangelo and the Trump. All of them "ok" but there was always something not quite right.The Mandarin is epitome of luxury. The staff, the rooms, you name it; I have nothing but positive comments.We booked the premier park view suite and were very happy with its size and view (there was some obstruction from the Trump next door, but hey, its New York City). We also, booked the Spa VIP Suite on a rainy Sunday afternoon. Oh my God! If you have a couple of grand in your pocket and would like to spoil your partner, this is the way!Every night when we left the hotel for dinner the hotel car was available (although I realize this was just luck with the timing). We will stay here on the next trip and probably will try some of the other Mandarin properties.Ok, one negative! The bar was closed when we came back to the hotel at 12:15 after dinner. However, that was a nightcap that I really did not need anyway!

I stayed at the Mandarin Oriental New York for five nights. Yes, it's a pretty hotel with a nice location. The spa is good but terribly expensive. I was disappointed with the service. Every morning room service got my breakfast order wrong. And it was a new mistake every morning. Quite annoying having to wait for them to get the order right - every day! At least they got my dinners right. Several times when I called housekeeping to ask for something to be delivered or done in the room, they forget or made a mistake and brought the wrong things. On several occasions the concierge forgot to call me back or to find out things for me. They also provided me with addresses to several shops, but did not provide a map, or the side street, or the opening hours. And I had to help them find out several things which should have been easy. All in all, the hotel does not provide the type of service one would and should expect from a five-star and very expensive hotel.

Stayed 1 night at the mandarin oriental in a Central Park view room. Was really looking forward to this stay as it was the most expensive hotel room we've ever stayed in ($1279 per night), so expectations were high. Prior to staying at the MO we had already stayed 6 nights in NYC in a mid priced hotel around the corner so this was our treat. To be honest I was a bit dissapointed. Yes the room was overlooking central park but a good proportion of the view was obliterated by the Trump tower which has been built right in front of the Times Warner centre (where the MO is housed on the top floors). We had also already seen the view of Central Park from the Top of the Rock so had already 'spoiled' it for ourselves - probably should have booked the room for our first and not last night in NYC. Room was nicely furnished but did not surpass any other 5 star property where you pay much less for a room. TV was infuriatingly difficult to operate if you wanted to browse the 100 or so channels. Breakfast at Asiate was divine - great service & food and highly recommended. Check in service helpful, efficient & friendly and as professional as you would expect for a hotel of this calibre. Hotel was more suited to business people not so much tourists and didn't have much of a holiday atmosphere. Did not use the spa or pool/fitness centre. Great shops & dining options in the Time Warner building.

Stayed here for New Years and had an amazingly romantic stay. Booked a room with a tub with view of city. I am not into taking baths but with that view and room service of some champagne and chocolate covered strawberries was worth it. The pool room is nothing exciting but the spa is def worth visiting. I had the massage which was ok but the best part of the spa experience was steam room and lounge which has amazing views of the park and city. The bed was soooo comfortable. Of course the rooms are on the smaller side but thats what you get for nyc. But even though the room was small it had everything you would need from a top hotel. If you are visiting nyc the location is great especially during the holidays. The hotel restaurants and bar are worth going to as well.

I chose this hotel based on recommendations from this site. Either I'm just hard to please or I had really bad luck with this experience. I booked a wkd trip with my mom in a suite - we were in town to see an oncologist for my mom. Having frequented many other hotels globally, luxury and otherwise, I was very disappointed. The door staff, who represent first and last impressions was terrible and didn't even come close to a mid-level hotel, let alone other 5-star hotels like a Four Seasons or a Ritz. On multiple occasions, they ignored us because they were too busy socializing with each other, doing blackberry(unbelievable!), or favoring other guests. We took many cabs and only once did we get assistance after we asked the doorman (this is after we tried hailing our own cab without any success right in front of him) - the doorman who was too busy doing his blackberry/phone and made us feel like we were rude for interrupting him. Doorman only held open door sometimes, seemed like only if he felt like it - it didn't matter if we had our luggage or not, it was very inconsistent. After being promised checkin to our room 30 min after we arrived, we took a 2 hr lunch and were surprised when they said that our room still was not ready when we returned - yes we were a few hours early but don't tell us it will be ready earlier if it won't be! This was not the welcome we needed especially due to my mom's fatigue. At least they treated us to a drink in the bar - but still all my mom wanted to do was rest. I was left on hold one night after asking concierge for some info - he forgot about me and I had to call back to get assistance from someone else. Upon leaving, we asked for an address and phone number to a Fifth Avenue store - the concierge gave us the wrong information (the address didn't exist and the number was for the corporate office, not the retail store). We ended up getting lost and I had to call my husband who was back home for navigation assistance - we ended up having to walk quite a distance to find the store (again, not good when my mother is ill) and had to rush our purchases before making it to the airport on time. If the conceirge could not find the info, he could have at least told us that rather than give us some bogus address on Fifth Avenue that did not even exist. The hotel did try to compensate for some of the bad service by not charging us for any balance of our breakfasts that our package did not include. But even that wasn't communicated very well and different messages were communicated by different people. I liked that the spa amenities were included in the suite rate - the steam room was good. But I've been to nicer spas. Location is good. The room was nice and I loved the bedside reading books and supply of Fiji water. The view from Asiate was beautiful. I was surprised that a newspaper was not included and the spa certificate was pretty much useless. I travel alot for business and have been to other hotels in NYC and I would not return to this hotel. This was my first Mandarin Oriental hotel stay - I had always preferred Peninsula for a luxury hotel with Asian flare. I didn't choose to stay there this time because their spa/gym was being renovated. Overall, I was extremely disappointed in this stay on many fronts. I could have stayed at the Sheraton and would have gotten better service!

Just few words to say and rate our great experience at the Mandarin Oriental New York. Have been there for a couple of nights at the end of July 2008. Booked a simply superior room with a main Hudson view. The room was not huge but very nice with a lot of useful tech advantages and features. The bed was very comfortable despite of some really soft pillows. Bathroom perfect in size and very nice. Service absolutely fantastic, very nice view also if it not was not a Central Park room view. Enjoy a wonderful breakast ( also if is the service it was a little bit too slow ) at the Asiate Resturant. Unfortunately did not use the Spa or other services. So , one if the not the best hotel in New York right now , also if it was expensive. I really like new and High Tech hotel and this Mandarin it was in my opinion a true perfect layout . Additional to this , check in and check out were perfect and very quick , as well room service . Bravo Mandarin !

Last weekend, I proposed to my girlfriend and we stayed two nights at the Mandarin Oriental. This is by far the best hotel we have stayed in New York. We received a complimentary upgrade and all the staff were absolutely perfect. I was considering other hotels where I have previously stayed including the Four Seasons, Waldorf Astoria, the Meridien, the Hudson or Alex and am absolutely delighted to have decided on the Mandarin Oriental. It is expensive but they do have special weekend offers and for such an occasion really lived up to expectations. I could not fault the hotel or staff in any way as it made this day very special. I think we will be coming back here for our important anniversaries. Absolutely worth spending a bit more to stay in a very special place with magnificient views and bedrooms, complete peace of mind in a relaxing setting and get what is probably the best service in New York.

Mandarin Oriental NYC is a fantastic hotel. We stayed in an executive suite facing the Hudson river (view from the living room) but we still had a view of Central Park from the Bedroom/Bathroom.The suite has a tremendous woaw factor, this is the best city suite we ever tried, even if not the biggest. However please note that service is not at the same level as it is at Oriental Bangkok (flagship of MO group). Small details have to be improved (butter was missing at breakfast once, trash can was not emptied every time at night service). Fortunately these small issues did not tarnish our experience.We used the Concierge services many times:- magical private helicopter ride booked through him with Helicopter Flight Services, Inc.,- reservation of one of the best table at Del Frisco's Steakhouse on 6th avenue,- transfer with limousine from/to the airport (205 USD from JFK and 180 USD to JFK => nice and helpful chauffeurs knowing the city to avoid traffic),- etc.We also tried the swimming pool & the Spa (on 36th floor). Therapists were smiling, very professional. Use of the VIP Spa suite is delightful. It allows you to enjoy time in your private steam and bath, finishing with a light dinner. You feel completely taken away from the city bustle. Regarding the location everything has already been said. You have direct access to the shops at Columbus Circle (with Whole Foods Market at the basement where you can have lunch/dinner at a fair price until 11pm). Many subway lines stop at Columbus. AMC Loews Cinema with IMAX is 15 minutes away (by walking), just like boutiques on 5th avenue and Times Square.

OK, so how is this hotel the 45th best hotel in NYC? You can argue over what is #1 and the Mandarin Oriental will always be in that conversation.The staff is impecable and attentive. I had lost some luggage on the flight from LAX and the concierge made sure American had it and got it to me promptly, I didn't need to do a thing.My room had an amazing view of Central Park and the meal at Asiate is as good as I have had in NY. YES, the property is pricey, but what in Manhattan isn't?For a business trip, especially on business with Time Warner, this place is hard to beat.

Just stayed at the Manadarin this past weekend. We celebrated our 25th Wedding Anniversary and the staff at the hotel created an exceptional expericance. From the moment we were greeted by the doorman to the moment he said goodbye on our last day, we were catered to as royalty. The staff was pleasent. caring and very accomadating. the location is the best in Manhattan, the hotel was beautifull. Very well organized , situated and very classy. The rooms were fabulous, we stayed in the Hudson River View room,, everything from bathroom, bedding to view was perfect, just like images on theweb site. The Lobby Bar was a great relaxing spot after our dinner & theatre evening.All staff were excellent and the class & service was the tops.

I've stayed at many luxury hotels both in NYC and around the world including the luxury masterpiece "Burj Al Arab" in Dubai.The Mandarin Oriental is superb. Above and beyond style and accessibility, the most important factor in considering the rating of a property is SERVICE.The service at the Mandarin is Superb. One of the best only rivaled by my time spent at the Four Seasons.If you're going to NYC, do NYC right, and stay at the Mandarin, where your every whim is addressed and you can focus on only your task at hand whether it be pure pleasure or business.

Had a great stay at the Mandarin Oriental... but might prefer the Trump Towers next time.... Why? Because I like an unobstructed view and Trump Towers obstructed the CP view big time... so I prefer to be on the first row next time. Sure the Mandarin Oriental is a 5-star... but somewhat overpriced.

My husband and I have been trying out various hotels in Manhattan in order to find the perfect one for us. So far this is the best. It has the views of the Four Seasons and the service of the Saint Regis all rolled into one. We booked a Central Park suite and were not disappointed. The bedroom can be completely shut off from the living room so that it's very dark and quiet. I slept better there than in my own home. The bathroom is quite large with double vanity sinks, private toilet room and large soaking tub. It also has a nice shower. There is also a powder room in the entrance foyer for guests. It happened to be nearly 100 degrees every day that we were there so it was nice to have the indoor shopping center on the first three floors of the Time Warner building without having to go outside. We also ate dinner at Asiate and it was fantastic. Room service was impeccable and we didn't have to send the waiter back for any forgotten items - a first. There are plasmas in the living room and bedroom as well. The staff is extremely friendly.

My husband and I stayed here for 3 nts for my birthday. It was worth every penny! From the moment we arrived, until the moment we left, everything was wonderful!The hotel not only upgraded us to a Hudson River View Room, but they had a cake & a bottle of champagne waiting for us for my bday. Since we don't drink, we thanked the bellboy & sent the champagne back. He came back 10 minutes later with a tray full of fruit and extra bottled water! The service was excellent! Everyone who worked in the hotel was gracious and hospitable, and always had a smile on their faces. The decor was beautiful and the views from the hotel, stunning. The room itself was well laid out and had great views. I loved their rainshower head! I had a facial & a massage at the spa. Although it was very expensive (more than most places I've been), the services were excellent. I don't think I've had such a great massage in a very long time! We had dessert & coffee in their lobby bar one night. Not only were the desserts great, but the view (esp. at night) was great!The location is good. You could walk pretty much anywhere midtown. Anywhere else, you would need a cab. Also, since they had shops & restaurants right below the hotel (Shops at Columbus Circle), it was very convenient to grab coffee or snacks, or even a meal.All in all, this was a great hotel and I would definetely go back in a heartbeat.

I went here in October im sure the service hasnt changed, but i have to say this hotel is stunning. We booked through Quintessentially/Carrier who made our stay perfect. Our room was styled to perfection. I love modern hotels, and with our limestone bathroom with rainfall shower and huge bed it was uber luxurious for my long weekend.The room was well equipped with a tantalising mini bar stacked with goodies like jelly beans, and the room service breakfast was quick though a little expensive was delicious. (I had the pancakes)Also on my birthday they brought up a tray of goodies like chocolate dipped strawberries and other goodies, it was the small details that made my trip memorable.We used their concierge, and they recommended some great places for food, all the staff from the door men to the reception were charming and helpful. We also dined in Asiate, all i can say is WOW! we feasted on asian style lobster and chocolate fondant (i still dream about that dessert) Pricey yes, but it was fusion at its best and the views are not to be missed, and again they gave me a little birthday cake creation.All in all, a true 5 star hotel. For a weekend of luxury, i would stay at the MO again.

I stayed at this hotel to try this hotel out. The indoor pool is a great size. The gym is a little on the small side, but well equipt. The service since I arrived has been amazing. The hotel is spotless and clean. The staff is excellent. The spa treatments I received were good, but not great. Hotel spas are always super expensive, but thought I would try a facial and a massage. The massage is great and the facial was a 7 on a scale of 1 to 10. The best waiting area and spa water ever. The room was very small with too many chairs. I had to take the extra chairs out of my room. The bathroom was very nice and the shower was excellent. The room overall, besides the over crowding of the furniture, excellent and clean. The bed was comfortable, and the sheets were very soft. If you are lucky, you will see a couple of famous faces in the lobby. The food was good. I would stay again.

The Mandarin Oriental in NYC is an absolutely gorgeous, 5 star hotel! My husband and I stayed there for a night after my grad school graduation and were completely blown away by the immaculate facilities, incredible location, and over-the-top friendly and attentive customer service. Each and every staff member you meet at the Mandarin Oriental have a genuine smile on their faces. The location of this hotel can NOT be beat for a visit to the city. I lived in New York City for three years, worked there for 5, and still hang out in the city several times a month. Columbus Circle, the Mandarin's location, is where you want to be if you are a tourist or a native New Yorker looking for an amazing stay. You are right at the hub of all the major subway lines, a short walk downtown to Times Square, 5th Ave Shopping, Museum of Modern Art, and a short walk uptown to Lincoln Center, Tavern on the Green, and the delicious restaurants of the Upper West Side. There is a bit less of the hustle and bustle of other midtown hotels located in the 30s and 40s (streets). Our room had the most spectacular view of central park and the upper west side - all rooms have views as the hotel lobby starts on the 35th floor.Go to the Mandarin if you can splurge!

After much deliberation, I booked this hotel for my husband and I for a 5 day stay.It left me torn between this and the Four Seasons. I enjoyed the decor and ambience of the Mandarin so much. Views were incredible. We were in a Hudson River view room and it was lovely. The washroom met and exceeded my expectations and this was my biggest concern after staying at the Four Seasons. Truly everything about the room was perfect and I cannot fault. From the cleaning, to turn down, I loved coming back to it and enjoyed being in it which is saying a lot for a hotel room. Public areas over the top in terms of decor and views. Service in the Lobby Lounge was awful as stated in previous reviews but you kind of let it go when you're just so happy to be there enjoying the view.It's a bit of a nuisance having to take two sets of elevators to get up to your room, but again you get over it - fast. The elevators are very efficient and smooth.We found the doormen, front desk, concierge staff all outstanding. We were offered rides in the hotel cars on a number of occasions.The spa was insanely expensive and I do mean insanely expensive, but the most luxurious spa I've ever been to - oddly the reception staff at the spa were not great in terms of service or competence. Would I do it again? No, I think I'd spend the four figures on dinner somewhere or a new handbag. Glad I tried it though.When booking the hotel and getting confirmations of same I was a little worried - things seemed somewhat unclear and disorganized, but when dealing directly with the hotel and concierge we were extremely happy on every level.My personal preference for location was the FS in terms of shopping on Madison etc., but if you enjoy the mall below the Mandarin then it would be the perfect place to stay - also it's very convenient to the subway if that is a priority. In summary, the FS washrooms are probably a bit better, but not by much, the room decor and ambience of the Mandarin was better in my opinion (not bigger - but better). Location is a personal preference. Service is almost as good as the FS, but as i said it's easy to overlook the shortcomings when you're happy on so many other levels. Give it a try! I would absolutely go back.

I stayed 4 days for leisure and had a great time. The view of Central Park (room 4508) was great and the room was very nice. The bed was comfortable. Turn down service in the evening with bottle water is great. The service is impeccable. I loved the "Do not Disturb" or "Make the room" done by a push of a button, that was cool.while I like the bar and the lounge area, breakfast is just ok (food overall is tasteless...): no white bread (olive bread in the morning is a bit hard with orange jam; croissant a bit greasy...), no assam tea (the darjeeling is excellent though). For diner, the wine selection is impressive but food again, is nothing to brag about.Concierges were very helpful and their recommendations quite good. Now the not-so-good part:- Shower: the door was banging 3/4th of the way against the marble so was not really convenient to walk in; to make matter worst, the 'ceiling shower' is just at the entrance, so you get wet when you start it and if you want to get in, then it better be at the right temperature...- Noise: i was surprised to see that there was no "second doors" provided that the room was not too far from the elevator; but the bad part was that you could hear all the conversations in the hallway. Truly the only negative point.- Table by the window: I asked a table by the window for breakfast the first day since there was one available. I was told someone reserved it, eventhoug I insisted. I finished breakfast and no one ever showed up to the table. So much for treating well your guest. I guess next time, I would just go to front desk and ask them to "solve the issue". The next morning same story, but I just ignored her and sat at the table...Overall, a very nice hotel with a very professional and helpful staff.

My husband and I just spent a weekend here for our anniversary, and virtually everything about this place is a wow -- including the price. We sprung for a Central Park-view room on the 45th floor, and it was the most amazing hotel view we've ever experienced (and at $1100 a night it should be). Our room view was even better than the view from the Lobby Lounge, so we ordered cocktails in the room one night and just relaxed on the backless sectional sofa that ran the entire width of our room right in front of the view. Total indulgence. True, the room was not overly large, but fine for NYC standards and elegantly decorated. My only minor complaint was the weird light switch in the bathroom: you had to hold it down for several seconds each time while the room gradually brightened or darkened. The Lobby Lounge is spectacular, with enormous windows overlooking Columbus Circle and Central Park. To be safe you should make a reservation because it fills up and people linger. (The smaller bar off in the corner is cramped and has no view at all, so don't bother. ) The Lounge hostess, Christina, was extremely accommodating, and once we were able to get a table, she kept "upgrading" us to ones with better views as they became available, even though we hadn't asked. In all, the service was excellent. This hotel is part of the Time Warner building, and you can access the shopping area by taking the elevator down to the third floor. We had a terrific stay and would definitely return -- that is, when we've saved up!

My first review on tripadvisor but had to write one for the Mandarin.Everything about my stay was superb. I was originally in a premier central park view room and moved to a deluxe twin as a friend came to join me for the weekend.Both rooms were excellent - with hindsight, I wasn't that worried about a view of central park, it was my first time in New York and felt I had to do it but if I was booking again (which I will be) I would go for the deluxe grade. The room was just as good.Every request made was fulfilled with courtesy, efficiently and guest satisfaction in mind. The only slight negative was breakfast in Assiate. Service was a let down and the coffee cool, but was replaced immediately.Ken on concierge was brilliant - I went to see him about getting to a Broadway show (which he booked) and he ended up planning an entire day of sightseeing for me, including a helicopter tour.My advice is don't hesitate to stay here, yes it's not cheap, but it's so worth the extra.

We (my wife and I) wanted to celebrate an anniversary, and figured that we would drop a little extra coin and stay at the MO NYC. From the minute we arrived nothing but service and style. I arranged for some fresh flowers to be in the room (peonies and chocolate cymbidium orchids)& utilized the concierge for some great dining advice! We stayed in a suite with an awesome view of central park, and used the location to walk to shopping, dinner, and even over to times square to people watch (should have skipped that -- crazy and dirty). We took the D train uptown for the Yankees game, and a quick cab to the meat packing district for dinner (10 minutes) at Vento. The location is great and the room is spectacular.

After booking a joint Cunard cruise with a stay in the Mandarin Oriental Hotel, the best part of the whole holiday was the stay in the Mandarin Oriental! We strayed in room 5012 overlooking Central Park, Room 3902 two single beds and room 5036 with distant views of the river. Everyone in the hotel from the front desk, concierge and housekeeping could not have been more helpful and everything was delivered and dealt with, with the minimum of fuss to the highest standard.Breakfast in the Asiate Dining Room was perfect and the service excellent with a most wonderful view looking out over Central Park.Meals in the Lobby Bar were excellent and on the second occasion service was slow and when the food arrived it was cold. The Manager took the initiative and waived the bill for the whole meal and a second serving of food arrived shortly after and was excellent. We thought that it was a good example of the standard expected in the hotel and that failure to deliver was taken very seriously by everyone – if only other hotels would adopt the same standard!The rooms were perfect and beautifully finished and even included a tray of sweets for our daughter, especially delivered for her.Overall the perfect experience in what was otherwise a disappointing holiday with Cunard.

I am just sitting at the airport lounge and just wish to share my 2 nights experience at the MO NYC. Almost everything has been exceptional:THE GOOD:* The lobby on the 35th floor: minimalist but warm deco, great view.* staff: I could not fault anyone in this hotel. Special greeting to the concierge, so so friendly and helpful. Always smilling.* Rooms: good size, very clean, high quality everywhere you look at.* BED: A dream!* Bathroom: gives you a feeling of relaxation through the colours and the delicate smell.* ASIATE Restaurant: clearly one of the most exceptional food I have ever had (believe me, I travel a lot and love eating), with an incredible combination of japanese and european flavours.THE LESS GOOD:* The quality of the bread (both at breakfast and dinner at Asiate):Compared to what is offered now in the US, they have a lot to learn (Try the bread at the Four Seasons 57 restaurant: a huge difference).* Bathroom amenities: More like a *** hotel.Anyhow, and without any doubt, I will come back to MO NYC !

April 15 Cathi Glasgow U.KJetlagged but had to write this while it was fresh in my mind, because I have found the comments of others so helpful when choosing a hotel...so excuse mistakes.Just back today after holiday at the Mandarin Oriental N.Y with husband and 2 teenagers and can honestly say that we all loved it. Yes it is expensive , room service / mini bar /spa very steep, but we knew that would be the case when we booked. Could not fault the service or the attention to detail and the bed was so comfortable that it was a joy to go to bed. The view from our Central Park suite was amazing at any time of the day or night.
